div1.p: Carter and LePrince describe a planned pond and the mosquito control measures that should be undertaken in constructing and maintaining it.

div1.head: Memoranda of Physical Survey of Portions of the Site to be Covered by the Water Impounded at Badin, North Carolina, by Henry Rose Carter and Joseph A. LePrince, [19--]
div1.p:
MEMO OF PHYSICAL SURVEY OF PORTIONS OF THE SITE
TO BE COVERED BY THE WATER IMPOUNDED AT BADIN, NORTH CAROLINA

From conversation with Mr. Hardaway and the Assistant
Warden at the convict camp, we learned that there had evidently
been much malaria in this immediate vicinity of recent years.
We also heard of this disease on the upper part of Beaver Dam
Creek. Even without this information we came across- we were
not looking for them- so considerable a number of places physically
well suited for breeding anopheles that we would have come to
the same conclusion. As these will generally be destroyed by
filling the pond they will not be especially enumerated. There
is no question that where people are thick enough there should be
considerable malaria in this country.

We aim to prevent or lessen the breeding of mosquitoes
and to do this by exposing their larvae (wiggle-tails) to wave
action and fish, which are the main agents that destroy them.

We can do little to influence wave-action as it depends
mainly on the shape of the shore. The removal of heavy drift
wood, however, will help this to some extent. To increase
the action of fish we can do much and at this place fish will be
in many portions of the pond our sole dependence against mosquitoes.

The larvae are protected against fish by small floatage next
to or against the bank, and our object is- first, to prevent its
formation, and second, to strand it up on the bank above water.
The latter method is by far the most efficacious. Naturally
all floating material that stays in the pond any length of time
will reach the bank unless prevented by some obstruction from
No. 2
doing so. If this happens when the pond is high it will be left
stranded upon the bank when the pond falls. We must then not allow
obstructions to exist, which will prevent this floatage reaching
the bank.

I will take then two datum lines- one, the 544 contour,
your ordinary maximum level, the lower contour 515505, not left bare
more than ten consecutive days.

list.item:
(1) Trees and brush completely submerged at all times are
of no importance and can be left. The same is true of such in the
pond (away from the bank) that do not reach above contour 505.
Hardwood trees anywhere in the pond are a matter of small importance
and need not be cut for sanitary reasons, though I understand
it is proposed to do so to prevent interference with the operation
of the plant. Pine trees, whose tops come above 505, should be
“ringed” (belted) or cut down this spring so that they may not cast
pine needles in the pond in the summer of 1917, and laps of trees
anywhere in the pond that will float up to the surface, are to be
removed or destroyed.

(2) Clear the edges of the pond of brush. Taking the
544 contour go up- say- three feet above it on very steep banks and
10 or 15 feet above it on sloping banks- measured on the surface.
Cut all brush that will stop floatage down to the contour 505 and
below it-say- three feet on steep slopes and 10 ft. on gentle
slopes. This stuff that is cut must be removed from the pond either
by dragging above the clear space or by a complete burning. All laps
down in this clear space must of course be removed.

item.p:
(3) When there are thick groves of hardwood sapplings
growing at any point within the clear edge, whose tops project above
No. 3
contour 505 and are so thick as to stop a considerable amount of
drift they should be cut down and removed. The same for the
brushy tops or trees not far from the shore line.

In our judgment this is all of the cutting that will do any
good as a sanitary measure, but I cannot lay too much stress upon the
necessity of removing the things cut from the pond. The stumps
on the upper contours of this edge should be cut as low as
possible, because if the water covers it most of the time the
stump will not throw up sprouts. If it does not, it will., It will
be necessary, I think, once or possibly twice a year, for the first
few years, to go over this edge above your ordinary high water line
to cut off the sprouts that come up.

It will not be necessary to do any of this work in such
parts of the pond as are- say- 1-1/4 miles from a residence, an
occupied house. This distance is in excess of what is deemed
generally necessary, but is specified as giving quite a factor of
safety.

list.item:
(4) If it be practicable, weather conditions may prevent it,
it would be of very great advantage to burn over the pond site, the
whole of it, just before it is filled, as close to the filling as
possible. This will get rid of leaves, pine needles and small
brush generally which would otherwise rise up and float on the
pond. It will also tend to kill the stumps that are above high
water level.

(6) With a pond in which there will be as large fluctuations
of level as this one it will be advisable to lockout and see if it
will leave pools or ponds as it falls, and if so, to drain them
by suitable ditches. Likely enough it will be impracticable to
No. 4
judge of this over all parts of the pond until after the pond is
filled and you see whether it does leave such pool. A pool
drained within fourteen or sixteen days of its formation does no
harm and a pool that does not last that time, by drying up or
otherwise, does no harm.

(7) Since you are depending mainly on fish for control
of the mosquito breeding in this pond I would advise you to make
arrangements for getting such fish, either this fall or at least
very early next spring, the former being preferable.

(8) The U. S. Fish Commission has a hatchery of mosquito
eating fish at Elizabeth City, N.C. Note that the fish you want
are TOP MINNOWS. Game fish would be a disadvantage to you
as they would eat the minnows instead of the mosquito larvae.
The minnows are needed in large quantities.

(9) SPECIAL LOCALITIES.
Referring to property map-
1. I do not think any of the willows here except those
next to the bank and next to the Whitney Dam are high enough to
require attention. Those next to the bank on both sides are
to be cut.
2. There is a lot of debris here, old trestles, etc.,
which should be removed, as they will float up when the pond is
low. Burn them.
3 & 4. Measures to be taken- Clearing of the brush, etc.,
are provided for in the general measures but they should be
taken with extreme pains and more brush removed than seems
necessary on account of their proximity to Whitney, which doubtless
No. 5
will have considerable population.
5. The old canal and bights that go off from it will likely
be a very troublesome proposition. Indeed a good part of the bottom
of this canal, especially towards the lower part, was probably
breeding profusely the last few summers. It is in every way
well fitted physically for breeding mosquitoes now. It, too, will
have to be cleaned more than ordinary and the edges and banks
kept clean more than is necessary for the rest of the pond.
This place is dangerous for three reasons.
It is close to considerable villages, Palmerville and
Whitney. It is so narrow that wave action will have no effect
and we will have to depend entirely upon fish. The sides are
so steep- vertical in many places- that the fluctuations of the
pond will not rid us of floatage.
The measures devised for the rest of the pond must
be acentuated for this canal and bights. It must be very carefully
cleared. The bank must be kept clear of floating material, by
hand I expect, and it must be especially stocked with fish.
I believe however that these places are in their natural con-
dition, producing many anopheles.
6. Is simply marked because all along the edge of this
cliff there is a very large amount of tree laps in the woods, some
of which would float up and hence should be removed.
7. In the lower reaches of Beaver Dam Creek most of the
stuff will be completely submerged and needs no attention. I
think the edges will require cutting.

10. The upper reaches of Beaver Dam Creek and Reynolds Fork
are in quite flat country and there are a number of farm houses
No. 6
empty around them. These places will probably be dangerous
as they are too narrow for wave action to do much good.
They are far less dangerous however than the canal.
1st. Because there are not nearly so many people.
2nd. In shoal water the fish have a great deal more
control of the mosquitoes.
3rd. The gentle slope of the banks allows floatage
to strand; hence, we should have clean edges.
An extra planting of minnows in this locality
is very advisable; also lookout for pools left
by the falling pond.

div1.p:
For the convenience of anyone making a biological survey of
this place during the summer, which should be done, as it would
throw much light upon its present condition in the productions
of malaria breeding mosquitoes. We would enumerate such of these
places which seem to us physically well suited for breeding
anopheles, as we have noticed. (See numbers on map).

list.item:
1. Back of the old Whitney Office site there are a number of
pools physically well suited for breeding.

2. Behind railway fill just below Whitney- two places
in upper part- one in lower.

3. Second bight below Whitney beyond the Winston-Salem
Southbound, a large area physically well suited for breeding.

4. In the valley of Beaver Dam Creek where the road crosses
it, not far from the river, at No. 7.

5. At No. 8 from the mouth of Buffalo Creek down to Beaver
Dam and between them, a large area are well suited for production.

6. At Glady Fork, where it joins Beaver Dam, the creek
spreads out into a number of pools extremely well suited for
breeding.
No. 7

7. A small place, Spring Head and Marshy Stream, to the
rear of Elliott's house, about 200 yards off. This may dry up
in summer time.

8. At saw mill beyond Elliott's house, a large breeding
place.

9. Beyond the abandoned house of J.C. Russell, a series of
pools in the woods.

10. At the crossing of Reynolds Fork near a saw mill, beyond
this place and at the crossing of the last fork of Beaver Dam Creek
where the land is very flat, are several large areas.

11. At two crossings of Reynolds Fork going back towards
the Yadkin, several pools on the side of the road in the woods
on the uplands going towards the Yadkin; one place in cat-tails,
in the race of the power plant.

div1.p:
It is not pretended that these are all or even any
considerable proportion of the breeding places in the area to be
covered by the pond. They are simply some that we noted as we
passed along part of its periphery.

list.head: CARE OF THE POND AFTER IT IS FILLED.
list.item:
1. Keep the winter level of the pond from October 1st to
June 15th or 30th as high as possible so as to strand all of the
floatage that comes to the banks at this time of the year when the
pond falls towards the summer level.

2. Save the summer floods, July 1st to Oct. 1st, as
much as you can so as to have the pond level fluctuate during this
season. It is understood that the summer level is less, by
some feet, than the normal winter level. The pond should not
be kept up during the summer time into the line of already stranded
No. 8
drift as long as three weeks, preferably not over two weeks. It
will generally be impossible to do this even if you wish it.

3. For the first few years we judge it will be necessary
to cut down the sprouts that will come up above your 544 contour.
Below that contour it should be kept clean of living growth, the
pond itself.

4. The edge of the pond should be examined from time to time,
between July 1st and Oct. 1st, so that collections of logs and heavy
drifts that may possibly land against the bank, and yet be floating,
can be dragged out. This will probably not be necessary after the
first of the year.

div1.p:
If collections of small floatage are seen resting against
the bank it, too, should be dragged out. The banks of the canal
and its bights from Whitney down should be given very special
attention in this respect, and will we fear require much attention.
It all depends on how efficacious the fish will prove here.

Nothing is advised to prevent the growth of aquatic plants
which in future may be a problem. This condition will have to
be met when it arises, if it does arise. We do not know enough
of this yet to advise general maneuversmeasures in advance.

The measures we have indicated above are about all that are
applicable for the control of mosquito (Anopholes) production
by this pond within allowable economic limits. They are in excess
of what we would feel justified in requiring, but are as specified
for the following reasons:
1. The very considerable number of people who will be
adjacent to the pond at Whitney, Palmerville and Badin.
2. The unusual risk of mosquito production entailed by the
canal and the bights behind the Winston-SalemRR track.
No. 9
3. The statement that you were prepared to carry out all
measures which would do good at any reasonable expense.

Even with these measures carried out it is not pretended
that there will be no anopholes production in the pond. There
will be. The total production of the pond site will likely be
no greater or less than at present, but the location of breeding
will be changed, and malaria may be increased in some places.
The measures advised should however minimize mosquito production and
this with proper screening, and possibly the use of quinine should
minimize the malaria in the community.

It must be noted that the increase in population adjacent to
the canal would increase the number of malaria cases among them,
even with no change in the condition of the breeding places.
This increase will be out of proportion to the increase in population,
rather as a funtion of the square, or possibly of the third power of
that increase, and this must be discounted in estimating the
malaria due directly to mosquitoes produced in the pond. It will
be the more noticeable as people come in from non-malarious
communities.

H. R. Carter
